courseDescription: An interdisciplinary examination of the African American experience in America.  The course examines the historical and contemporary conditions of African American people.  It also explores the various modes of artistic expression, values and philosophical underpinnings of African American culture.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication about historical and contemporary issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on African American experience

courseDescription: This course offers students a critical approach to interpreting the history of Africa. A fast-paced survey of African history, it affords students a grounding in the major themes of African history. The course focuses on the major economic, social, and political institutions of Africa, past and present, and explores how historical developments assist comprehension of present-day Africa.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital tools for historical analysis

courseDescription: Required of all history and secondary education social studies majors. Recommended prior to upper-division course work. Examines methods of historical research and primary and secondary source analysis, inclusive of internet usage. Explores historiography and historical writing. Introduces students to issues in the philosophy of history.
Covers the design and implementation of quantitative and qualitative methods of inquiry in social sciences.

courseTitle: Human Rights and Social Change in Africa
courseDescription: This course examines historical social movements in Africa such as economic, ethnic, women's, political, and religious social movements.  This course will also link micro-level, meso-level, and macro-level implications for the social structures and cultures of various African nations and communities.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engagement with diverse political and social perspectives
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of social structures and cultures

courseDescription: This course is intended to familiarize students with the struggles, advances, and setbacks of African peoples for state-building and socioeconomic development during the colonial and post-independence eras.

This course is an introduction to social research methods.  The primary purpose of this course is to survey the major research designs and research techniques that are the core of contemporary approaches used to study social phenomena as well as the lives and experiences of African Americans.  Ethical implications of social research and data analysis will also be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding ethical implications of social research
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing experiences of specific groups (e.g., African Americans)
Identification and resolution of ethical issues in research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research projects with ethical consideration

courseDescription: Examination and explanation of minority families' lives in relationship to other societal institutions and historical developments. The course focuses on issues of minority families and places these issues in a sociological framework, e.g., stratification, poverty and gender.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and communicating complex social issues

courseDescription: The course examines African-American history from the African background through the Civil War. Emphasis is placed on an analysis of African-Americans' role in the political, economic, social and cultural life of the United States.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using digital tools for historical analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical events and their impact
Understanding and interpreting economic and political systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on historical contexts

courseDescription: Individual practical experience in community-based organizations, public bureaucracies, administrative agencies and other organizations and firms.  Student can gain exposure in the not-for-profit and profit sectors.
Technical and Digital Skills: understanding of not-for-profit and profit sector operations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: effective communication within public and private sector organizations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing practical problems in organizational settings
applying theoretical principles to real-world issues

courseDescription: This course surveys the political, social and cultural history of colonial and post-independent Africa. Major themes include colonization and resistance, anti-colonial movements, social and cultural transformations, urbanization and popular culture and post colonial challenges.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Articulating complex political and social concepts
Oral and written communication of historical narratives
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on complex historical themes

courseDescription: These courses are open to majors and non-majors.  Ethnic studies majors may take these courses to satisfy requirements for the concentration.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of historical and social contexts

courseTitle: Africana Intellectual Thought and Economic Development
courseDescription: This course examines Africana philosophical and theoretical thought as it pertains to issues of race, labor and production.  Through an examination of the social and economic legacy of slavery and colonialism, this course investigates how systems of exploitation have influenced the underdevelopment of Africa, the Caribbean and North America in its contribution to Western Capitalism.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching and examining social and economic legacies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Critical evaluation and discussion of race, labor and production issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing systems of exploitation and their socioeconomic effects
Assessing the impact of slavery and colonialism on economic development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and structuring complex historical and socio-economic information
Leading discussions on sensitive and complex topics

courseTitle: Politics of the Civil Rights Movement
courseDescription: Examines the political activities which resulted in the passage of the nation's second Civil Rights policy, the 1960 and 1964 Civil Rights Acts, the 1965 Voting Rights Act and the 1968 Fair Housing Act. The course will analyze the underpinnings, leadership, and political strategies of the Civil Rights Movement.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and engaging with diverse perspectives
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of historical events and legislation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding leadership roles and strategies in the Civil Rights Movement
Evaluating and understanding the impact of organizational structure on political outcomes

courseTitle: African American Political and Social Thought
courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to the historical and contemporary experiences of “Blackness” as it has been constructed, contested and affirmed in various historical, political and narrative contexts.  Embracing the theme of duality, the course examines what it means for a culture and people to be both integral to and excluded from the American political and social community. This is a writing intensive course.

The study of the process of and responses to the oppression of racial, religious, ethnic, and national minorities in a variety of countries within a historical and comparative perspective. Special emphasis given to American minorities and especially African Americans.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy and understanding towards different cultures and ethnicities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in the context of social inequality

courseDescription: This course will examine the intersectionality of race, ethnicity, crime, justice and the operation of the criminal justice system and will critically assess controversial issues surrounding race, ethnicity, crime, and justice. Students will discuss contemporary social justice issues as they relate to race, ethnicity, crime, and justice. The theoretical frameworks that explain the intersection between race, ethnicity, crime and justice will be examined. The course will also investigate the broad range of policy issues and recommendations impacting communities of color and the administration of criminal and social justice.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and application of intersectionality theory

courseDescription: This course examines the impact of diversity, culture, and ethnic origin in criminal justice organizations. The course is designed to better prepare students to meet the challenge of diversity in criminal justice organizations.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective professional communication in diverse environments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of diversity in criminal justice organizations
Developing strategies to address diversity-related challenges
Understanding and interpreting cultural and ethnic origins
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Promoting a culture of inclusion and respect

courseDescription: This course examines the issues and perspectives related to the psychological evolution of African Americans in the United States. Particular emphasis is placed on exploring the discipline of psychology from an Afrocentric focus.

courseTitle: Introduction to Critical Race and Media Studies
courseDescription: In this course, students examine how media culture - both historic and contemporary - contribute to the intersectional production of race in the United States. A guiding question will be: How do media and popular culture - as texts, practices, industries, and sites of identity formation and pleasure - construct race? Although students will theorize the politics of representation, they will also work to situate texts within a larger historic, political, and discursive context in order to assess the type of cultural work they perform.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Contextual assessment of cultural work by media texts

courseDescription: This course will introduce students to the key concepts involved in developing and executing an interdisciplinary research project.  Students will read and interpret research literature, execute a research project, write a final research paper, and present research findings in a professional setting.

This course focuses on a variety of selected topics in African American Studies.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

Students are exposed to opportunities to conduct independent research and/or study in areas focused on the political, social and cultural experiences of people of African descent in the U.S. and the African Diaspora.

Students are exposed to opportunities to conduct independent research and/or study in areas focused on the political, social and cultural experiences of people of African descent in the U.S. and the African Diaspora.
